qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: Calling family and friends; my son shows me YouTube videos occasionally.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: Yes, husband and children use it daily for calls or videos; it’s an old phone.

qa.question: What are your favorite apps or features on your phone? Why do you use those apps? Have you ever thought about what information these apps might be collecting?
qa.answer: I mostly use calling. My son uses YouTube and WhatsApp; I haven’t thought much about data collection.

qa.question: When an app asks for permission, like to access your location, camera, or contacts, do you read and understand what it means?
qa.answer: No, I usually press Allow; my son helps me if I ask.

qa.question: How do you decide whether an app or website is safe to use?
qa.answer: I trust apps my family or neighbors use; if they say it’s safe, I use it.

qa.question: Have you ever deleted a message, photo, or app because you didn’t want someone to see it?
qa.answer: No, I don’t use many apps or keep private things.

qa.question: If your phone stops working and you need to give it for repair, what do you do before handing it over?
qa.answer: I give it as it is; I don’t know how to delete or back up data.

qa.question: Have you ever asked someone (friend/repairer/child) to help you with a phone problem? How did you feel about them seeing your personal data?
qa.answer: Yes, I ask my son or the repair person; I don’t mind because I don’t keep private things.

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: My family; I don’t share private things outside the family.

qa.question: Have you used code words, nicknames, or indirect language to keep something private?
qa.answer: No, we speak directly in the family.

qa.question: Have you ever helped someone install or use an app? What did you explain to them?
qa.answer: No, I haven’t helped anyone with apps.

qa.question: Do you know how to stop an app from using your camera, microphone, or location?
qa.answer: No, I don’t know how to do that.

qa.question: When you get a warning message (e.g., 'this app may harm your phone'), what do you usually do?
qa.answer: I ask my son or the repair person what to do because I don’t understand the message.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you give an app access to your contacts or photos?
qa.answer: I think the app just needs it to work properly; I haven’t thought much about what they do with my info.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair because of private content?
qa.answer: No, I don’t hesitate because I don’t have private content.

qa.question: Has a repair person, friend, or shopkeeper ever opened your gallery or apps without asking? How did you feel?
qa.answer: Sometimes repair people look at the phone; I don’t mind because I trust them.

qa.question: Do you use a password or lock screen on your phone? Why or why not? Does anyone else know your password?
qa.answer: No, I don’t use a password because it’s difficult to remember; my family helps me use the phone.

qa.question: Do you think apps from local developers are safer than international ones? Why?
qa.answer: I think local apps are safer because they are made in our language and by people we know.

qa.question: Who do you turn to when you don’t understand a phone or app setting?
qa.answer: I ask my son or neighbors for help.

qa.question: Do people around you influence the way you think about online safety?
qa.answer: Yes, my family tells me to be careful and not share passwords or personal details.

scenarios.Broken Phone: Give phone for repair as is; don’t delete anything because I don’t know how.
scenarios.Sharing with Family: If husband or children use the phone and I get a private message, I usually keep it and don’t hide apps.
scenarios.Installing a New App: If an app asks for permissions, I ask my son before installing.
scenarios.Helping Elderly Relative: I would try to explain simply what the app does, but mostly my children help them.
scenarios.Using a Borrowed Phone: If I see a private photo or message on a friend’s phone, I ignore it.
scenarios.Selling or Giving Away a Phone: I usually give the phone away without deleting anything because I don’t know how.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: I don’t know about cloud backups; my son sometimes deletes things for me.
scenarios.Using Free Public WiFi: I avoid public WiFi for important things like banking.
scenarios.Receiving a Lottery Call: I don’t trust those calls and never give my details.
scenarios.Sharing Account Details: I don’t share bank details; only my husband or close family if necessary.
